primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The Son of God descends from divine glory into human slavery and death to rewrite the 'book of love' that humanity ruined, thereby transferring humanity from a state of 'ugliness' (sin) to 'beauty' (grace).

subject.identificatie: The Son of God / Christ Jesus
tekstueel_bewijs: He stepped into our place and lived out the story the way it was supposed to be lived

object.identificatie: The 'Book of Love' / Salvation / Reconciliation with the Father's Will
tekstueel_bewijs: He rewrote the book of love in his own life
brought us into the safety of his realm of perfect love forever

zender.identificatie: God the Father / The Divine Will
tekstueel_bewijs: The will of the Father and the Son together
perfectly obedient to our heavenly Father
You and I are the 'ugly people'
This love now is given to you and to me

helper.identificatie: The Holy Spirit (implied) / The Word and Sacraments
tekstueel_bewijs: we receive it into our hearts when we hear this Word
into our hands when we come to Communion
helper.rol_van_god: God is the Subject, not merely a Helper.
helper.rol_van_geest: External help through Word/Sacrament that becomes indwelling power.

tegenstander.identificatie: Sin / The Disobedient Will / Death / The State (Cross)
tekstueel_bewijs: death on a cross... specifically designed to be as degrading and dehumanizing as possible
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: The opponent is not just bad habits but a 'godless' state and a 'messed-up will' that humans cannot fix themselves.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The ethical response of the church: living in unity and humility.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Believer / The Congregation
secundair_narratief_programma.object: Unity / The Mind of Christ / Miracles of Love
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The secondary program is explicitly grounded in the success of the primary program ('Because he has rewritten the story, we do not have to be prisoners...').

actantieel_schema_visualisatie.helper_subject_tegenstander: The Father's Will → Christ Jesus ← Sin/Death/Human Rebellion
actantieel_schema_visualisatie.subject_naar_object: Christ Jesus → Rewritten Book of Love

voorbeelden_god_subject: He has brought us into the safety of his realm
He is going to make us beautiful
voorbeelden_mens_subject: we receive it into our hearts

voorbeelden: Paul says he hopes that all the people... complete his joy
What steps can you take to rewrite your own story?
We forget that we are here because of a staggeringly new thing
we aren’t and we can’t and we don’t [obey]
The Son of God is the only one who could do that
we do not have to be prisoners of our worst selves anymore

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon focuses on human 'non-pouvoir' (inability) and Christ's 'pouvoir' (sovereign ability) to rewrite the narrative. Ethics is framed as a 'pouvoir' granted by the primary action of God.

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: Moves from the 'Fantasy' of human effort (~S2) to the reality of our 'Ugliness' (~S1), then into the 'Godless Death' (S2) where Christ takes our place, finally resolving in 'Divine Love' (S1).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: Christ occupies S2 (the death of a slave) to transform ~S1 (the ugly people) into S1 (the beautiful/rich).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: Very high; the sermon emphasizes the dehumanizing nature of the cross and the godlessness of the human reaction.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: The sermon consistently maintains God/Christ as the active Subject of salvation. Human action is described as either failure (sin) or a secondary response to God's prior action.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: What steps can you take to rewrite your own story?

indicatoren_genade.indicator: God as Subject of active verbs
indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: He stepped into our place and lived out the story the way it was supposed to be lived.
The Cross reveals to us just how godless we really were.

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: While Paul is mentioned, he is not the hero; Christ is the only one who could achieve the 'Big Idea'.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: The sermon already treats them as 'receivers' of grace rather than models of virtue.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief and joy; the burden of 'rewriting' is shifted from the hearer to Christ.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The transition from the 'Big Idea' (Soteriology) to the 'Church fights' (Ethics) is logically linked by the 'Mind of Christ'.
spanning_punten: The shift from 'Christ rewrote the book' to 'What steps can you take to rewrite your own story' creates a slight actantial tension.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: He stepped into our place and lived out the story the way it was supposed to be lived.

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: Endowment of 'the mind of Christ' to the incompetent human subject.

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Total inability; even 'good things' are done for selfish reasons.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The sermon is a robustly theocentric narrative where Christ is the hero-subject and the congregation is the rescued-receiver.

modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: The move to 'Vouloir' at the end is appropriate for a call to action.

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: A masterclass in maintaining the 'Grammar of Grace' while addressing a diverse audience including children.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: Rhetorical analysis would focus on the Laurie Anderson hook; semiotics reveals that Anderson is actually the 'False Sender' of a 'Fantasy' value system.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis explains the Greek 'morphe'; semiotics explains how that 'morphe' functions as a modal competence for the Subject.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Reveals that the 'ugly people' are the Receivers of a value (Object) they actively tried to destroy (as Opponents), highlighting the radical nature of the grace-economy.

volledige_subject_lijst: Christ (emptied, humbled, became, rewrote, brought, gives)
We (messed up, put to death, receive, fight)
appendices.notities: The sermon uses the 'Ugly People' metaphor to bridge the gap between the high Christology of Phil 2 and the psychological reality of the hearer.
